fields.value: Uniform Crime Reporting Program Data [United States]:  Police Employee (LEOKA) Data, 1998

authorName.value: United States Department of Justice. Federal Bureau of Investigation

authorAffiliation.value: United States Department of Justice. Federal Bureau of Investigation

dsDescriptionValue.value: Since 1930, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has  compiled the Uniform Crime Reports (UCR) to serve as a periodic  nationwide assessment of reported crimes not available elsewhere in  the criminal justice system. Each year, this information is reported  in four types of files: (1) Offenses Known and Clearances by Arrest,  (2) Property Stolen and Recovered, (3) Supplementary Homicide Reports  (SHR), and (4) Police Employee (LEOKA) Data. The Police Employee  (LEOKA) Data provide information about law enforcement officers killed  or assaulted (hence the acronym, LEOKA) in the line of duty. The  variables created from the LEOKA forms provide in-depth information on  the circumstances surrounding killings or assaults, including type of  call answered, type of weapon used, and type of patrol the officers were on.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XVII.E. Social Institutions and Behavior, Crime and the Criminal Justice System
